title: Labour conference: Ed Miliband's speech, with reaction and analysis - Politics live blog | Politics | The Guardian
summary: ed miliband 's speech - a reading list .
ed miliband 's speech - reaction from business .
imperial tobacco says labour 's tax plan 'totally unwarranted '
lib dem president tim farron says miliband had no ideas on tackling deficit .
ed miliband 's speech - verdict from the twitter commentariat .
george osborne criticises miliband for not mentioning deficit .

text: michael white is the keeper of the guardian 's diary at conference , here 's his round-up of the day : amid the mixed reviews for ed miliband 's supersized speech , the taxpayers alliance , billed as britain 's non-partisan grassroots campaign '' ( for a tory victory ) , was fearless .
it condemned ed for sixth form socialism of the most uninspiring kind '' which wo n't raise promised billions from tpa supporters .
the tpa 's own sixth form idea for targeting plutocrats is its annual town hall rich list '' , some of whose entrants earn more in a year than rupert murdoch does in a week .
asda , the supermarket chain not in trouble over dodgy profits reporting , runs a mumdex survey of shoppers concerns .
it did so on the conference fringe where shadow home secretary , yvette cooper , was guest speaker .
being labour women , the audience voted more child care '' their no 1 concern and no one asked for more police on the beat . ''
i 'm clearly at the wrong meeting , '' said cooper , but gracefully .
it 's that man again .
labour heavyweights turned out to help launch , the blair ascendancy , a scholarly account of new labour by lewis minkin , meticulous historian of the party conference .
among those present , david blunkett loyally defended the boss.others claimed to have been deceived by his reformist salami-tactics after labour 's defeats in the 80s .
none more so than blair 's once-faithful deputy .
nowadays tony is all about money , money , money '' but during the iraq war he was putting on a white cover with a red cross , going on his crusades . ''
yes , pensioner prezza , free at last , has spoken again .
more glimpses of life in the yvette cooper/ed balls family from the conference fringe .
this summer they took their three kids inter-railing ( you do n't have to be 21 and smelly to go inter-railing '' ) .
en route they joined a sound of music bike tour of salzburg , birthplace of julie andrews and mozart , so real ed confesses .
if there photographic evidence of ed in lederhosen , would lord leveson let the mail print it ?
a nightmare for sadiq khan , shadow justice secretary and wannabe london mayor .
he 's on a city devolution panel and finds the panel is wall-to-wall bloke .
i apologise it 's an issue for me , '' says khan who also took pains to sit as far away as possible from a giant mayor of london '' poster .
he does n't want to be a private eye cover before he 's even won .
quote of the day : justine thornton : on a more personal level it seems to me it 's about whether principles and decency count for something in public life .
it 's about ed , and all the other politicians who try to do the right thing despite the personal attacks so those are the reasons why i am up for this fight over the next eight months .
however nasty , however personal , however brutal it gets over the next eight months , i am up for this fight . ''

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: ed miliband has set out his pitch for what he described as his job interview with the british people for the post of prime minister .
in his final party conference speech before the general election , he cleverly part-appropriated the better together '' slogan that won in scotland by asserting together '' as his core idea .
that was the ethic that would allow the country to succeed , he said .
in an unusual move , he also set very long-term goals , setting six targets for 2025 .
his vision is bold , although the policy ideas accompanying each goal are probably not on their own sufficient to guarantee success .
miliband delivered his speech without notes , which apparently led to him forgetting to included a passage on the deficit .
george osborne has said his silence on this shows labour can not fix the economy .
miliband also repeatedly referred to people he has met around britain to show he understands the concerns of ordinary men and women .
labour figures have praised the speech , but commentators have generally been more negative .
here 's what miliband said about his job interview '' .
friends - you know , i know , that the next eight months represent my interview with the british people for one of the most important jobs in our country .
let me tell you what i care about .
i care about big ideas that can change our country .
the principle of together .
i care about hearing the voices of people right across our land and not shutting them out .
and i care about something else .
i care about using the power of government to stand up against powerful forces when we need to do so .

it came home to me the other day , when i met rosie , a doctor from devon , and she said to me : what we need is someone who will stand up for working people , for everyday people , because you will have the power and we wo n't . ''
that 's why i stood up to rupert murdoch over phone hacking .
that 's why i stood up to the banks over bonuses .
that 's why i stood up to the payday lenders over their exploitation of the poorest people in our country .

that 's why i stood up to the energy companies over their profits and prices and , yes , it 's why i stood up to the daily mail when they said my dad hated britain because i know my dad loved britain .
miliband said labour would set up a £ 2.5bn time to care '' fund capable of supporting 20,000 more nurses , 8,000 more gps , 5,000 more care workers and 3,000 more midwives by 2020 .
it would be funded by a levy on tobacco companies , a £ 1.1bn clampdown on tax avoidance including by hedge funds and a mansion tax on houses valued at more than £ 2m .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: ed miliband 's speech - a reading list
text: here are some of the more interesting blogs i 've seen on the miliband speech .
andrew harrop at the fabian society says this was the most fabian speech he has heard from a labour leader .
ed set out six fundamental , structural changes that he wants to be the defining goals of his government .
each will take years to achieve , through successive waves of reform .
but in each case , to begin the journey , ed set out a package of reforms that are bold but also achievable .
the specifics announced today may not prove sufficient by themselves , but with the goals now locked down , labour will be able to recharge its batteries in office and go further .
george eaton at the new statesman says the speech failed to inspire the hall .
the awkward truth for labour is that there was little in the speech to convince those not already inclined to vote for the party to do so .

and after miliband acknowledged his weaknesses in his speech in the summer , there was little to persuade the large number of voters who do not regard him as a future prime minister to take another look .

rather than sweeping to victory , carried aloft by the progressive majority '' , the growing sense is that the best labour can hope for , as one shadow cabinet minister put it , is to fall over the line '' .
david clark at shifting ground says that miliband had a vision , but that at the centre of the speech was a good old fashioned spending commitment '' .
james kirkup at the telegraph says this sounded like a speech from a leader preoccupied with the core vote .
overall , this was a speech - and a conference - that suggest a party more preoccupied with its own voters than the other side 's .

a speech that will only bolster the sus that mr miliband believes that if he can just win back enough votes from the liberal democrats ( the original advocates of his mansion tax policy ) and add those votes to the labour core , then he will just nudge ahead of a conservative party hobbled by ukip and still struggling to persuade those same middle-of-the-road folk that it 's on their side .
he might well be right , too .
matthew taylor at the rsa got particularly excited by one passage .
there was one paragraph that set my pulse racing .

here it is : 'the ethic of the 20th century was hierarchy , order , planning and control , rewarding the talents of just a few , then the ethic of the 21st century is co-operation , everybody playing their part , sharing the rewards and using the talents of all .
together .
it 's time we ran the country like we know it can be run ' sadly , this big idea was n't developed leaving the togetherness theme to feel merely rhetorical , albeit clearly heartfelt .
isabel hardman at coffee house says that this was a poor speech , but that it was probably good enough to appeal to the labour base .
here 's the full text of ed miliband 's speech .
here are two of stefan rousseau 's two best miliband photographs .
stefan rousseau ( @ stefanrousseau ) photo du jour : ed miliband delivers his keynote speech to the labour conference .
by stefan rousseau/pa stefan rousseau ( @ stefanrousseau ) photo du jour pt 2 .
ed miliband and wife justine leave the hall after his conference speech .
by stefan rousseau/pa
and here 's some more reaction .
from frances o'grady , the tuc general secretary this was a speech that spoke to the real problems and worries of working people - jobs , living standards , homes and a secure future for the nhs .
its policy agenda , genuinely ambitious but believable , is exactly the way to reconnect politics to voters .

from david sparks , chair of the local government association it is encouraging that ed miliband has pledged to devolve greater powers to local areas and reiterated the lga 's call for a constitutional convention .
local government has long been making the case for greater freedom from whitehall to create jobs , support businesses and tackle the issues that matter most to people .
earlier this year we set out proposals for the next government to devolve powers to local areas to insulate homes .
today 's endorsement of the lga 's idea is good news for the thousands who would stand to benefit from localised energy efficiency schemes .

from doug parr , chief scientist for greenpeace ed miliband today showed he understands the scale of the climate challenge and made some real steps towards shifting the uk economy onto a greener path .
it 's a path which leads to a vibrant economy , better , warmer homes and the million green tech jobs he talked of .
people will welcome the jobs and prosperity a greener economy will bring , but these benefits will only be delivered by cleaning up our power sector , and that means getting rid of coal .
ed needs to take a stand against this government 's planned multi-billion subsidies to prop up the big six 's dirty coal plants .
it 's what the people want .

documents.title: ed miliband 's speech - reaction from business
text: here 's some business reaction to the speech .

from john cridland , the cbi director general there 's no doubt that ed miliband has ambition for britain and we share his desire to build more homes , raise living standards and remain in a reformed european union .
but we heard very little about how to create the economic growth to deliver these ambitions and the crucial role of healthy and thriving businesses in creating prosperity for all .

from simon walker , director general of the institute of directors this was an opportunity for ed miliband to demonstrate that he is on the side of britain 's small businesses , entrepreneurs and wealth creators .
it was an opportunity to show that his party understands and values the role that british business plays in creating jobs , driving prosperity and supporting communities .

unfortunately , the only reference to business was a caricatured broadside against corporate failures , which is in fact a million miles away from the risk , sacrifice and hard work of the small and medium sized businesses that account for 99 % of all companies in this country and 60 % of private sector jobs .
from john longworth , director general of the british chambers of commerce at this conference , labour has repositioned itself positively in respect of its business and economic credentials .
however , ed miliband 's speech did not really focus on the economy and wealth creation as much as we had hoped .

it is slightly problematic that some elements of his speech are likely to be seen as short-term political expediency , and could create uncertainty for business which runs counter to the need for long-term strategic vision and investment .
from steve nash , the institute of the motor industry 's chief executive ed miliband has set out an interesting plan for increasing and improving the level of vocational training in the uk .
one of the major obstacles to attracting talented young people into our industry is the negative attitude of their parents towards apprenticeships compared to university education .
a cultural change at the heart of government policy in this area would go a long way to overcoming this barrier .

documents.title: imperial tobacco says labour 's tax plan 'totally unwarranted '
text: the tobacco industry has reacted angrily to ed miliband 's plan for a new levy on them .
my colleague angela monaghan has sent me this .
britain 's tobacco industry reacted with fury to ed miliband 's plan to tax british cigarette companies to pay for nhs spending , branding it anti-business and unjust .

imperial tobacco , behind brands including lambert and butler and golden virginia , said labour plans to raise at least £ 150m by taxing companies according to market share amounted to an attack on a legitimate business sector .
a spokesman for the company said : the idea is totally unwarranted and unjust and should be dismissed immediately .
imperial is already one of the largest contributors of tax to the uk government in the ftse 100 , contributing billions of pounds in tax and excise every year .
the uk tobacco industry is subject to a punitive high rate of excise , meaning the average total tax take on a pack of cigarettes is 86 % .
the idea put forward today fails to acknowledge the wider contribution made by imperial to society , and will place further pressure on jobs and livelihoods .
earlier this year we announced the closure of our nottingham cigarette factory citing in part the impact of excessive tobacco regulation and taxation . ''
jeremy hunt , the health secretary , says ed miliband 's plans for the health budget do not match what the coalition has already achieved .
jeremy hunt ( @ jeremy hunt ) miliband says £ 2.5bn more for annual nhs budget , c. 2.2 % real terms .
we delivered 4.4 % real terms increase - see ifs

rowena mason has been looking into some of the other ordinary people '' miliband talked about in his speech : beatrice bazell , a phd student studying victorian women 's bodies in art , believes she and her friend helen were quoted by ed miliband after a chance encounter on hampstead heath .
the labour leader recounted how he had met two students from a top university in london recently and one of them said her generation is 'falling into a black hole ' .
he joked that they had wanted to meet the actor benedict cumberbatch and ended up with him .
bazell outed herself as one of the 'cumberbatch-fanciers ' on twitter .
as commentators cast doubt on whether some of miliband 's encounters had actually happened , she said : 'i refuse to question whether i exist .
but i bewail my failure to come up with a more elegant metaphor when faced with a politician . '

documents.title: lib dem president tim farron says miliband had no ideas on tackling deficit
text: here 's tim farron , the lib dem president , on the speech .
the country needs a bold roadmap for the future and all we got was a wayward ramble around a north london park .
with every new announcement we are reminded why we can not trust labour with our money .
in an hour-long speech , miliband offered no ideas on how to tackle the deficit .
promises go underfunded , uncosted or use money that 's been spent many times over .
we are still waiting to hear labour 's big ideas , still wondering if the party that crashed the economy can be trusted to get back behind the wheel .
natalie bennett , the green party leader , says ed miliband 's proposals are too timid '' .
what mr miliband is offering are tiny steps on the right direction .
but this timid approach does n't reflect the need for real change in our society .

just as yesterday 's offer of £ 8\hr by 2020 means only a 25p a year increase for struggling workers instead of the living wage they need and deserve , the mansion tax is only a limited part of the wealth tax proposed by the green party that would ensure rich individuals made a fair contribution to the society they live in .
labourlist has got a good selection of reaction to ed miliband 's speech , with contributions from rowenna davis , owen jones , marcus roberts , stefan stern , emma burnell and anthony painter .
this is from stefan stern .
that was a clever , well judged speech .
‎the better together theme has now been purloined by the labour party － it reminded me a bit of tony blair adapting the football 's coming home song in 1996 .
‎it was a long speech , but that is no bad thing considering the size of the task and the scale of the ambition .
the six goals are big and important .

ignore twitter and the attention span of some hacks that would embarrass a goldfish : this was a serious speech from someone who is getting ready to be prime minister of an ambitious reforming government .
in eight months ' time he will be .
here 's len mccluskey , the unite general secretary , on the speech .

ed miliband 's speech today gave a clear message of hope to the millions of people who have suffered under the cruel economic and social policies of the coalition since it came to power in 2010 the keys of number 10 are within his grasp .
he is the only political leader that can re-energise a united britain to face the daunting economic , social , constitutional and foreign challenges that lie ahead .
matthew taylor writes with an update about gareth : the man repeatedly referenced in ed milliband 's speech is a former liberal democrat supporter who is now considering switching to labour .
gareth edwards , 36 , told the guardian he spotted the leader of the opposition on a park bench near his north london home on hampstead heath .
'you know when you spot someone famous and you take a sly look and he must have seen me and said hi .
i think he just thought it was time to have a chat to someone , ' edwards said .

miliband asked edwards what he thought the biggest issues facing the country that needed to be fixed , before edwards ' colleagues , who were enjoying a nearby , joined them to have their photo taken .
edwards , who said he does not follow politics closely , said the pair talked for around five minutes - mainly about housing , adding that he was impressed with miliband 's attitude .

'he was very interested and sincere and engaged in our conversation , he was interested to hear what i had to say he was genuinely interested in what i had to say rather than preach to me or push his agenda or anything .
i was impressed . '
edwards who lives with his wife and five year-old daughter said he voted lib dem last time but was now tempted by milliband and labour .
the guardian was not the first person to try and contact gareth .
according to colleague soulla josephides his mum had called moments before asking if he was the gareth miliband had mentioned .
here 's grant shapps , the conservative party chairman , on ed miliband 's speech .
ed miliband puts himself forward to be prime minister , but he failed to offer any serious plan to grow the economy - he did n't even mention once how he would reduce the deficit .
all ed miliband offers is more wasteful spending , more borrowing and more taxes .
you ca n't fund the nhs if you lose control of the nation 's finances and bankrupt the economy like labour did last time .
labour simply do n't have a long-term economic plan to secure a better future for britain .
our country , our children and our grandchildren would be worse off under ed miliband 's weak leadership .

documents.title: ed miliband 's speech - verdict from the twitter commentariat
text: here is a selection of some of the most interesting twitter comments on the speech from journalists .
from sky 's joey jones joey jones ( @ joeyjonessky ) can feel the speech is going to get panned .
labour was cursing bad luck of syria strikes dominating agenda , but may be blessing in disguise !

from the independent 's steve richards steve richards ( @ steverichards14 ) ed m speech- 'together ' theme is smart , but speech poorly structured and all the stories about people he has met shd have hit cutting floor .
from channel 4 news 's michael crick michael crick ( @ michaellcrick ) # lab14 can anyone please explain what equal rights for the self-employed , promised by ed miliband , might involve ?
from channel 4 news 's paul mason paul mason ( @ paulmasonnews ) okay so miliband not exactly nye bevan in the rhetoric dept but nhs pledge big , real and new ; elected senate & 16 y.o .
votes also ( 1/3 ) paul mason ( @ paulmasonnews ) miliband ( 2/3 ) - labour market reforms i.e .

self-employed are macro policy ; aim is to turn employment growth into wage growth paul mason ( @ paulmasonnews ) miliband ( 3/3 ) ; nothing really said on deficit ; nothing on national security - at times sounded like cabinet office not downing st agenda .
from newsnight 's ian katz ian katz ( @ iankatz1000 ) did i miss it or did miliband not mention `` one nation '' once ?

truly a one conference wonder # labconf14 from the daily mirror 's kevin maguire kevin maguire ( @ kevin maguire ) instant miliband speech verdict : thoughtful but needed more fire in his belly # lab14 from the guardian 's owen jones owen jones ( @ owenjones84 ) a fair enough speech , delivered fine .
the radical coherent alternative many of us want ?
not there .
# lab14 from the daily telegraph 's james kirkup james kirkup ( @ jameskirkup ) ed miliband can give pretty good speeches .
not sure that was one of them .
from the daily mail 's andrew pearce andrew pierce ( @ toryboypierce ) ed miliband ordered shadow ministers to limit speeches to 700 words .

he should have applied the rule to his own from newsnight 's duncan weldon duncan weldon ( @ duncanweldon ) two things that are usually in miliband speeches and were n't today : 'one nation ' & talk of reforming capitalism .
from sky 's faisal islam faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) not history , not soaring oratory .
slow start consciously little mention of deficit , migration , welfare .

labour thinks can win on core vote from the spectator 's james forsyth james forsyth ( @ jgforsyth ) not since david cameron in the 1st tv debate has a politician recounted so many conversations with people he met james forsyth ( @ jgforsyth ) suspect speech wld have been a lot better if it had n't been for scotland absorbing all labour 's energies in past month .
it needed tightening james forsyth ( @ jgforsyth ) most effective bits of mili speech were the attacks on the tories .
they have 2 find a way 2 rebut idea they are the party of the privileged james forsyth ( @ jgforsyth ) mili speech was n't a big tent one .
but in a 4 party system , enthusing the base and toxifying the tories might just be enough to get him home from the bbc 's norman smith norman smith ( @ bbcnormans ) hmmm .

not sure that ed miliband speech is going to change the political weather # lab14 from the sun 's tom newton dunn tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) my verdict on ed 's # lab14 speech : far from his finest hour .
together theme decent , but delivery weak .
not an election winning barnstormer .
from politicshome 's paul waugh paul waugh ( @ paulwaugh ) overheard .
one lab mp to another labmp after edm speech .
: '' well , i can remember four of the six points `` paul waugh ( @ paulwaugh ) wonder if edm considered mentioning today 's rising deficit figures in speech ?
or worried a hostage to fortune ?
at 2.21pm we brought you the playlist in the hall warming up the crowd for miliband 's speech .
here 's the review of it by guardian music writer tim jonze : it 's no surprise ed miliband chose to soundtrack his labour conference speech with pharrell williams ' happy .

after all , that song begins with the line : it might seem crazy what i 'm about to say , '' which is almost certainly gears you up for a ty high-octane and unpredictable e-mili speech in which he imposes a tax on eels and vows to invade scotland at least twice a year .

on the other hand , the possibility remains that the labour leader might have chosen happy not because of it 's coded lyrical messages about foreign policy but simply because it repeats the words happy '' , happy '' and happy '' over and over again , and the british public have become so slack-jawed and apathetic they will resort to associating the song 's unrelenting positive vibes with everything miliband says henceforth .
so what of the other songs ?

the mildly funky green garden by laura mvula 's could be sending a radical environmental message babout sustainable futures - not least because the ringing bells make it sound like you 're in glastonbury 's green future 's field , where you have to pedal a bike just to peel your own self-grown potatoes .

again , though , the track 's overarching vibe - gospel handclaps , intertwining voices - is probably the real reason behind the song choice : songs like this give you a mildly uplifting feeling while breaking no laws , the herbal highs of the party conference world .
as for embrace 's follow you home come on , it 's an ed miliband speech !
what did you expect ?
4 bit by aphex twin ?
at the end of the day , miliband is n't here to throw a sick rave , he 's more concerned with getting his message across .
and his message is as clear as it is bold : vote labour and britain will be vaguely upbeat in a non-threatening manner .

documents.title: george osborne criticises miliband for not mentioning deficit
text: george osborne has responded to the speech .
george osborne ( @ george osborne ) ed miliband did n't mention the deficit once .
extraordinary .
if you ca n't fix the economy you ca n't fund the nhs
on twitter beatrice bazell says she was one of the women who met ed miliband in the park .
beatrice bazell ( @ beatricebazell ) @ helenmgoodman we were just quoted by ed miliband !
cumberbatch-fanciers that was us , right ?
# goodlord beatrice bazell ( @ beatricebazell ) @ patrickwintour i 'm surprised he did n't remember our names ( 'beatrice and helen ' ) though he was polite enough to ask our phd to too !
according to her twitter page , beatrice is a researcher on victorian women 's bodies in art .
my colleague matthew taylor writes : the hunt is on to find gareth - the man named repeatedly in miliband 's speech .
he appears to be gareth edwards , a cambridge graduate working for london software company softwire .
colleague soulla josephides told the guardian that the company had been having a on hampstead heath near milliband 's home in august when the labour leader walked past and decided to stop and chat .
she said : 'he was having a stroll in the park and came over to join us he seemed very friendly and relaxed .
i did n't talk to him directly but he stayed for 10 minutes the first time and then came back again a bit later . '
there is now some confusion over of gareth circulating on twitter .
there are a couple going round showing softwire employees with milband .
it appears that gareth is the man on the very far left of this photograph ( below ) with his face partially obscured which tallies with this linkedin profile of a gareth who works at softwire .
softwire technology ( @ softwireuk ) that 's gareth , back left rt @ twitterid : ed miliband happened to stop by the annual @ twitterid as you do .
here 's guardian video of boris johnson condeming the mansion tax idea as a tax on london '' .

documents.title: verdict from denis campbell , the guardian 's health correspondent
text: here 's a snap verdict form denis campbell , the guardian 's health correspondent .
my first impression of ed miliband 's big nhs pledge - a new £ 2.5bn a year time to care fund ?
it 's a very smart move , politically and practically .
on the surface it appears to be perfect politics : a potentially very popular policy , to enhance the uk 's most cherished institution , that is also painless for voters - who will all benefit .
does the nhs need more money ?
yes , plainly , as its increasing struggle to cope with the relentlessly rising demand posed by ageing and unhealthy lifestyles shows .
who could possibly say no to more nurses , gps and midwives , allowing all health professionals to spend more time with them , or their loved ones , when ill ?
so who pays ?
not you or i or almost anyone we know .
instead it 's them - tax avoiders , those in £ 2m houses and big tobacco firms .
sympathy for any of them paying more to fund the nhs will be almost invisible .

it 's also easy to sell , a useful point of differentiation with the conservatives - who may now feel obliged to come up with their own ideas for extra money for the nhs - responds to a genuine need and reaffirms labour 's already strong standing as the party to trust on the nhs .
with the caveat that i 've not yet digested the detail , this seems like an astute move that could help really labour in the runup to the election .

documents.title: ed miliband 's speech - my snap verdict
text: snap verdict : after his brilliant speech to the 2012 democratic convention bill clinton explained its success by saying that explanation is eloquence '' and it seems that ed miliband was trying to take this advice on board in a speech with a strong , explanatory spine .
unusually for a party conference speech , it had a coherent , logical structure , and it was light on oratorical flourishes .
the together '' line might stick , but otherwise it was hard to think of a memorable phrase .
all this made it admirably serious .
but - let 's be honest - it was also a bit tedious .

miliband may have suffered , too , from the fact that his big nhs announcement came out early ( not intentionally ) , and his endless references to gareth , colin etc make the speech ripe for parody .
earlier this year miliband claimed that empathy was a key quality for a leader , and these real people '' anecdotes collectively reinforced the impression that he 's a good listener .

but this was probably overdone , and if i were david cameron 's speechwriter , i would already be working up a passage for cameron 's conference speech about how labour policy is now being decided , not by the leader , or the shadow cabinet , but by whichever stranger miliband happens to meet in his local park .
that 's just my snap verdict .
i will post other views soon .
and tell us what you think btl .
ed miliband kisses his wife justine thornton after making his keynote speech .
byrne/pa
miliband says he needs people to support him in this mission .
together we achieve much : building business , caring for the sick .
so together we can rebuild the country , he says .
on our own we can not do these things .
but we can together .
britain has to choose whether to be an on-your-own society , or a together society .
together we can make that happen , he says .
and that 's it .
it 's over .
miliband turns to the other guy '' ( david cameron ) .
cameron stands up for the wrong people , miliband says .
but what he objects to most about cameron is that he thinks a good photo opportunity will persuade people he is standing up for them .
before the election , cameron hugged a huskie .
afterwards , he said he would get rid of the green crap .
miliband mentions other inconsistencies .
and he says cameron thinks rebranding the bedroom tax the spare room subsidy '' will make the problem go away .
so there is a choice at the election : leadership that stands for the privileged few , or leadership that stands up for you .
miliband talks about standing up to news international , and to the daily mail when it said his dad hated britain .
his dad loved britain , he says .
( this gets a prolonged round of applause . )
britain has made such progress on gay rights , he says .
this has been the biggest transformation .
but that has not happened around the world .
miliband says he is appointing michael cashman , lord cashman , as his envoy on lgbt ( lesbian , gay , bisexual and transgender ) rights around the world .
miliband says he will fight with every fibre of his being to get a two-state solution in the middle east .
miliband says the uk 's future lies in the eu .
but europe needs reform , he says .
miliband says you achieve reform by building alliances .
david cameron tried to block jean-claude juncker 's appointment .
he lost 26-2 .
but he could have won .
why did he lose ?
because people thought he was only interested in solving a conservative party problem .
if you are elected president of france , you do not see solving tory problems as part of your job , miliband says .
he says this would happen again if cameron were re-elected .
to achieve reform in the eu , you need to win 28-0 .
miliband invites the audience to applaud carwyn jones , wales 's brilliant '' first minister .
he cites those who have campaigned for social justice .
some people will say being proud of being english is divisive .
but people care about social justice in the whole of the uk .
miliband says he will not let people drive us apart .
and if david cameron cares so much about the union , why is he seeking to divide people ?
cameron is learning the wrong lessons from scotland .
he is playing political tactics .
he does not lie in bed at night thinking about the united kingdom .
he is thinking about the united kingdom independence party pandering to them is one more reason why is is not fit to be prime minister .
miliband says he need to change the way power is shared .
he says labour would give 16 and 17-year-olds the vote .
it would reform the house of lords , making it a representative senate , he says .
and it would give more powers to cities like manchester .
but this can not be a westminter stitch-up .
there has to be a proper constitutional convention , he says .
we are four countries in one , he says .
each nation makes its contribution .
we are not just better together .
we are greater together .
people need good public services , miliband says .
and especially the nhs .
he recalls his visit to the hospital in watford .
he met colin , who told him what life was like before the nhs .
in those days , without the nhs , you really were on your own , miliband says .
he says labour 's next task is to build a world-class 21st century health service .
one in four people can not get to see their gp in the week .
and home care is a scandal .
people are getting visits of just 15 minutes .
we need doctors , nurses and healthcare assistants who have time to spend with their patients .
he says labour will create 3,000 more midwives , 5,000 more care workers , 8,000 more gps and doctors and 20,000 more nurses .
and it will pay for this by cracking down on tax avoidance by hedge funds , by having a mansion tax , and by raising extra money from tobacco firm .
( there are more details in patrick 's story here . )
there will be a time to care '' fund worth £ 2.5bn , he says .
labour will repeal the health and social care act .
we will rebuild the nhs , he says .
and we will do it together .
miliband delivering his keynote speech .
kitwood/getty images
miliband says by 2025 he wants britain to be building as many homes as it needs , doubling the number of first-time buyers .
it wil take a massive national effort , he says .
a new generation of garden cities will be built .
labour will get britain building again '' .
miliband introduces someone who is an apprentice .
by 2025 , he wants as many people to be an apprentice as go to university , he says .
this is a huge undertaking .
we are a long way away from this .
business and government will have to lead a revolution in this .
government have been absolutely useless '' in terms of promoting apprenticeships .
and that is true of governments of both parties .
firms must offer apprenticeships for the next generation .
in it , the number of apprenticeships is falling .
employers will get control of the apprenticeship budgets .
but if they want government procurement contracts , they will have to offer apprenticeships .
miliband turns to green jobs .
there will be a green investment bank , and , as caroline flint will announce tomorrow , labour will allow 5m homes to be properly insulated .
( actually , she announced it today , ed .
see here . )
miliband says his second goal is to ensure that , as the country gets richer , people get richer too .
there has to be a massive national effort , he says .
there should be much bigger '' reform of the banks , he says .
this would bring the competition we need '' .
and whitehall is too centralised .
power should be decentralises , so communities can create the jobs and the prosperity they need .
unions and government should engage in cooperation .
and he mentions another group that labour has not talked about much : the 5m self-employed .
they have an insecure life .
many do n't have a pension , or can not get a mortgage .
labour 's task is to end this discrimination and deliver equal rights for the self-employed in britain '' .
miliband says one in five people who work end up in low pay .
labour wants to change that .
it wants to transform the lives of 2m people .
the principle of together means we do n't just use the talents of all , we reward the talents of all .
labour would raise the minimum wage .
this could be worth £ 3,000 a year , he says .
miliband says he will set out his six priorities .
then he turns to nick clegg .
when clegg broke his promise on tuition fees , he damaged trust in politics .
people get more cynical .
there needs to be a route map out of this , he says .
that is what the plan is about .
( twitter tells me # together is starting to take off . )
cameron likes playing tennis and surfing .
let 's give him more time for this from next may , miliband says .
miliband says cameron will tell voters that he has done a brilliant job and that , if people just hang on , things will get better .
but this is one of the worst governments ever .
there has been the biggest fall in living standards since 1871 .
cameron says it 's not his fault .
but is n't there a more plausible explanation ; that the tories only make the economy work for the few .
the british people can not afford another five years of david cameron .
miliband says someone on a zero-hours contract is on their own .
if you are in the private-rented sector , you are on your own too .
the tories do not believe in government intervention .
but if you are a millionaire needing a tax cut , you are not going to be on your own .
and if you are a banker worried about your bonus , george osborne will go to europe to fight to protect it .
you certainly wo n't be on your own .
if you are a conserative-supporting , putin-supporting millionaire , you wo n't be on your own .
you 'll be on the tennis court playing tennis with david cameron .
that tells you all you need to know about this government .
miliband says this idea also operates in our brilliant '' national health service .
he spent two days in a hospital in watford .
mostly he got in the way .
but he saw people working together .
and he was so proud of them .
and the same applies in the military .
he pays tribute to them .
the ethic of the 20th century was hierarchy and order , he says .
but the ethic of the 21st century is cooperation , he says .
miliband says this idea is everywhere around us , in every walk of life .
he mentions gareth , who works in a software company .
it is full of bright people .
but everyone at the company said the same thing ; you need to use the talents of everyone .
and other businesses say the same .
that is the ethic of busineses in the 21st century .
britain needs great entrepreneurs .
but entrepreneurs recognise they are only as good as their team .
miliband arrives on stage .
neal/afp/getty images miliband delivering his speech .
scarff/getty images
( for a party conference speech , this has an unusually coherent and logical structure . )
miliband says labour will call time on this .
can it build a different future ?
of course .
but it needs a different idea .
the idea is rooted in this country 's history .
it can be summarised in one simple word : together .
together we can build a better future , and together we can rebuild britain .
miliband says working people have been told they are on their own .
young people think their life will be worse than their parents ' .
they have been told they 're on their own .
in politics , a few have access .
others have been told they 're on their own .
no wonder people have lost faith .
that 's why so many people voted to break our country .
people are saying this country does not care about them .
and they are not wrong , they are right .
and this labour party is going to put it right .
the other day he was in his park .
he had been working on his speech .
two people came over.one said you meet famous people here .
the other said they were hoping to meet benedict cumberbach .
one told him the country was falling apart .
miliband mentions another person , gareth , who said the county only worked for the privileged few .
people like that have lost their faith in the future .
ed miliband speaking to the labour conference today .
news
miliband mentions another young woman .
she lives in the opposite end of the country from scotland .
she works in a pub kitchen .
life is hard .
and she thinks politics is rubbish .
she sees drift .
she does not think it will solve problems .
we have to prove her wrong , he says .
miliband says we can build a better life for you and your family .
and this speech is about how to do that .
we have to explain why people voted to leave the uk , he says .
he starts with a story .
he met a woman in scotland .
she was a cleaner .
he asked what the company was like .
the company was right , but the wages were rubbish , she said .
she was thinking of voting yes .
he does not know how she voted .
but he knows the question she was asking ; is anyone going to make my life better ?
that is the question people are asking across the uk .
that was not just the referendum question .
it 's the general election question .
the uk almost broke up , he says .
he thanks those people who campaigned to keep the uk together .
he starts by mentioning gordon brown ( who he forgot to mention yesterday , when doing a similar exercise . )
and he wants to tell the people of scotland they made the right choice because we are better together '' .
miliband says he feels older than when he was elected leader - a lot older .
but he is prouder than ever to be labour leader .
( miliband 's passage on isil was quite cursory , and did not tell us anything new about whether or not labour would back air strikes . )

documents.title: ed miliband 's speech
text: ed miliband is speaking now .
he starts with the islamic state ( isis ) .
david cameron and barack obama are both at the un .
the un needs to play its part .
there should be a resolution to counter the threat from isis ( he calls it isil , but isis is our style ) , he says .
this country will never turn its back on internationalism , he says .
ed miliband is not having much luck with his timing today .
dave lee travis has just been found guilty of indecent assault , which is another story ( see 2.10pm ) soaking up 24-hours news attention that would otherwise be paid to the labour leader .
patrick wintour has more details from the speech .
here 's his full story , and here 's how it starts .

a £ 2.5bn time to care '' fund capable of supporting 20,000 more nurses , 8,000 more gps , 5,000 more care workers and 3,000 more midwives has been unveiled as the centrepiece of ed miliband 's speech to labour conference promising to bring britain back together .
labour plans to find the cash through a levy on tobacco companies , a £ 1.1bn clampdown on tax avoidance including by hedge funds and a mansion tax on houses valued at more than £ 2m .

miliband , hoping defence of the nhs can take him over the election line next may , balances the promise of extra cash with a commitment that we are going to have to transform the way the nhs works in the year ahead '' .
the guardian 's scoop about labour 's proposal tax on tobacco companies has hit their share price , my colleague angela monaghan reports .
she 's sent me this .
investors have not taken kindly to the news that ed miliband would impose a windfall tax on the profits of uk tobacco companies .
before the details were made clear in miliband 's speech , shares in british american tobacco and imperial tobacco were down by around 1.5 % , underperforming the rest of the market .
analysts pointed out that the bigger impact would likely be on imperial tobacco , which has a larger uk market than british american tobacco , but both companies would be hit .
the industry would argue that it is already paying a fair share towards the nhs , contributing around £ 12bn in 2011/12 revenues in excise duty and vat .
the cost of smoking to the nhs is estimated at between £ 2.7bn and £ 5.2bn .
goldman sachs ' analysts warned a windfall tax on profits might prove less effective than labour hoped .
for example , uk companies might try and reduce uk profits by lowering cigarette prices in britain , and raising them in other markets .
miliband would not be alone in his tough stance on tobacco .
president obama has sharply increased tobacco duty in america , first in 2009 when it was increased to $ 1.01 per packet from 39 cents .
earlier this year he proposed another major hike , from $ 1.01 to $ 1.95 from 2015 , with the proceeds to be used to fund pre-school education .
the president claimed it would raise $ 78bn over a decade .
us tobacco companies were furious .
the national association of tobacco outlets said the rise would disproportionately hurt lower income households , with an estimated 29 % of smokers living below the poverty line .
it also argued tobacco retailers would have to close stores and cut jobs as sales fell .
here 's the playlist in the hall .
siraj datoo ( @ sirajdatoo ) i shall be tweeting the playlist from ed miliband 's speech .
first up is happy , which is last year 's song of the summer # lab14 siraj datoo ( @ sirajdatoo ) now on : green garden by laura mvula .
# lab14 h/t @ twitterid siraj datoo ( @ sirajdatoo ) now we 're listening to embrace 's follow you home .
hope someone is analysing this cc @ twitterid2015 # lab14
ed miliband ( @ ed miliband ) i 'm about to speak to labour conference about our plan for britain 's future .
watch follow @ twitterid for live tweets​
ed miliband will speak for 80 minutes , the bbc reports .
according to the sunday times ' tim shipman , labour officials are trying to get people to turn their phones off in the hall .
tim shipman ( @ shippersunbound ) told to turn off mobile phones ahead of miliband 's speech .
apparently they want no social media coverage !
i will be disobeying this edict if so , they do n't seem to be having much success .
emily thornberry mp ( @ emilythornberry ) waiting for ed # lab14 @ twitterid miliband # forthemany
in normal circumstances ed miliband would expect to enjoy wall-to-wall coverage on the live tv networks .
but president obama is making a statement at about 3.20pm about the air strikes against isis , which means miliband may find himself bumped from sky and bbc news .
and miliband 's speech also coincides with alex salmond 's first speech to the scottish parliament since the referendum , which bbc news are showing live now .
refresh the page to watch ed miliband 's speech live above .
here 's the scene in the hall where ed miliband will soon be speaking .
rob chapman ( @ robertachapman ) great atmosphere at # lab14 as we wait for @ twitterid miliband

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: chuka umunna , the shadow business secretary , has said that the mansion tax being introduced by labour to help fund the nhs will only affect a tiny proportion '' of owners .
ed miliband is due to set out more details in his conference speech shortly .
labour has already revealed that he will use the speech to set out a six-point plan for transforming britain by 20205 .
( see 8.46am . )
umunna has signalled that labour could back air strikes against islamic state ( isis ) .
douglas alexander , the shadow foreign secretary , is calling for a un resolution on isis , but labour is not making this a precondition for backing air strikes .
manuel cortes , general secretary of the tssa transport union , has called for wholesale nationalisation of the rail , energy and water industries .
friends of the earth has welcomed a commitment from caroline flint , the shadow energy secretary , for labour to properly insulate 5m homes over 10 years .

donna hume , a friends of the earth energy campaigner , said this was a major step forward , benefitting households struggling with energy bills , and boosting efforts to cut britain 's carbon emissions . ''
simon danzcuk , a labour mp , has called for the barnett formula to be scrapped and for scottish mps to be banned from voting on english-only laws .
we should be saying that it 's not acceptable for scottish mps to be voting on english only laws , first and foremost .
we should also be saying that as a party , we 're not happy with the barnett formula and how it readjusts money in favour of scotland and against places like england and places like rochdale .
diana holland , labour 's treasurer , has revealed that the party is a step nearer its goal of becoming debt-free by june 2016 after it ended last year with an overall surplus of £ 5.5m .
as the press association reports , holland told the conference the party had gone from a net liability of £ 24.5m in 2006 to £ 2.6m seven years later - a reduction of almost £ 22m .
caroline flint , the shadow energy secretary , had a line in her speech earlier that caught the attention of sean kemp , a former aide to nick clegg .
sean kemp ( @ sean kemp ) great lines from political speeches : 'conference , let me tell you three things about sweden ' ( flint , 2014 ) .
here are those three things .
conference , let me tell you three things about sweden .
it 's colder than the uk , but you probably knew that .
its energy is more expensive than the uk .
you may not have known that .
so why does the johansson family in stockholm have lower bills than the johnson family in stockport ?
the answer ?
simple : swedish homes are super-insulated , keeping warm using less energy .
my plan is not just to freeze energy bills .
but , in the next phase of our reforms , to enable millions of people to permanently cut them .
flint said in her speech that she was declaring war on cold homes '' .
and , as well as reaffirming labour 's commitment to freezing energy bills , she outlined other measures to help people cut their fuel bills .
labour will get to work : half a million free home energy reports a year , so families know where and how they can cut their bills .
for those on low incomes we will make 200,000 homes warm every year , using every penny of the energy company obligation .
and unlike this government , we 'll get the job done properly in one go and put local authorities and communities in the driving seat .
and conference , private landlords will have to play their part .
our ambition is that private rented properties will have to meet a decency standard by 2027 , bringing warmth to three million homes .
and to ty home owners , i say : labour will provide one million interest free loans in the next parliament , so you too can heat your home and save on bills .
conference , five million homes more energy efficient .
all without spending any more money or adding to anyone 's energy bill .
douglas alexander , the shadow foreign secretary , is calling for a un resolution on islamic state .
he 's issued this statement about the overnight air strikes .
we understand and support the action taken by the us and arab allies in recent hours .
both the prime minister and the president are due in the united nations this week so we are now urging a resolution should now be brought to the security council of the un .
according to party sources , the fact that labour is calling for a un resolution does not mean that it will refuse to back military action if there is no resolution .
david cameron is also pressing for a un resolution .
mary creagh , the shadow transport secretary , addressed the conference earlier .
here are some of the main points in her speech .
creagh said labour would introduced the biggest reform to the railways since privatisation .
a labour government will deliver the biggest reform of the railways since privatisation to deliver a better deal for taxpayers and passengers .
we will bring network rail and a new passenger rail body together to coordinate track and train operations , and look after passengers .
we will tackle the monopoly market for rail rolling stock .

we will cap fares , legislate to allow a public sector operator to be able to take on lines and challenge the train operators on a level playing field and devolve decisions on rail services much closer to communities .
we will put the passenger back at the heart of the railway , not the profit motive .
she said the next labour government would make a swift decision on airport expansion in the national interest '' .
she said labour would let any city introduce london-style integrated tickets for buses ( ie , oyster cards ) to have them .
buses were a cinderalla service '' , under the coalition , she said .
rachel reeves , the shadow work and pensions secretary , came unstuck on lbc this morning .
nick ferrari asked her how much the basic state pension was .
around £ 100 , she replied .
he told her it was £ 113 .
you can read the transcript here .
lbc say that reeves did better than jeremy hunt , the health secretary , who said £ 85 , and harriet harman , labour 's deputy leader , who refused to answer .
( it 's actually not a simple question .
the £ 113 figure is based on a full national insurance contribution record .
there are more details in this dwp paper - pdf . )
rachel reeves ( left ) on the platform yesterday with her sister , ellie reeves , a member of labour 's national executive committee rousseau/pa

documents.title: tssa general secretary calls for wholesale nationalisation
text: manuel cortes , general secretary of the tssa transport workers union , called for wholesale nationalisation of the rail , water and energy industries in a speech earlier .
he got a very good reception in the hall .
cortes was opening a debate on an emergency motion on rail .
the motion itself does not call for bringing the entire rail network into public ownership ( see 11.25am ) , but cortes did not let this hold him back .
here 's the key extract .
you know , public ownership is not a crackpot , leftwing idea .
in the last decade 86 cities across our planet have brought water into public ownership .
in the united states , the cradle of neo-liberalism , cities like atlanta and indianapolis have brought water into public ownership .
the same is true of the great cities of europe , of berlin and paris .
and in what is the most successful economy in europe , in germany , since 2007 over 100 energy concessions have been brought into public ownership .

i tell you , if it 's good for the americans , if it 's good for the germans , if it 's good for the french , it must also be good for our people when you 've got a country like ours , where so much power and wealth is concentrated in so few , social justice will remain an utopian dream , a utopian dream , unless public ownership is part of the strategy .

and that is why i want each and every one of you to join us , to join the millions of people in our country who are clamouring for public ownership of our railways and whilst we 're at it , let 's bring water and energy too into public ownership .
let 's follow america .
let 's follow germany .
let 's follow what the french are doing .
ed miliband has joined instagram .
and he 's used it to post a with a page from his speech .
and while we 're on the subject of air strikes , jack straw , the labour former foreign secretary , told today he would be in favour of air strikes against islamic state ( isis ) in iraq .
we 're part of the western alliance , we have key interests - direct and indirect - in the region , so in principle we should be involved provided the circumstances are right .
but he was more cautious about britain backing air strikes against isis in syria .
this is what he said when asked if he would support that proposition .
it depends on the circumstances .
syria only if there is consent of some kind by the syrian government .

there are quite big legal problems if there is n't consent and i know there are discussions taking place in new york at the moment , or will be when they 're up , about a proper legal base for military action .
earlier i left a crucial not '' out of a post .
chuka umunna said downing street had not asked labour to support air strikes , not that it had .
i 've amended that now .
( see 9.37am . )

delegates are now debating an emergency motion on rail that urges labour to keep the east coast line in public hands and says labour should keep lines in the public sector if this , on a level playing field , provides best value for passengers and taxpayers '' .
the motion was introduced by manuel cortes , general secretary of the tssa transport union .
cortes turned it into a full-blooded call for the nationalisation , not just of rail , but of the energy and water industries too .
i 'll post the quotes shortly .

documents.title: eagle says labour would tighten regulation on water companies .
text: maria eagle , the shadow environment secretary , used her speech to the conference to commit labour to tightening regulation on water companies .
we need a new deal with the water companies and labour will deliver it - focused on affordability and fairness for all .
we will reform the industry , creating a national affordability scheme - compulsory for all water companies - to help people struggling to pay their bills wherever they live in the uk .
and in addition to more transparency for the first time , under a labour government , we 'll give the regulator new powers to modify the terms of water company licenses .
licenses first granted 25 years ago , when much of the industry was privatised - and largely unchanged to this day .
but times have changed along with company structures and ownership and we are seeing increasingly exploitative behaviour by some .
the water companies were making excess profits , she explained .

after more than four years of david cameron and nick clegg , water companies - which made over £ 2 billion in profit in 2013 - paid £ 1.8 billion of it in dividends to their shareholders and only £ 74 million in tax .
conference , that 's 90 per cent of their profit paid out in dividends - mainly to foreign hedge funds and anonymous private owners - the privileged few .
yet rather than make water companies support customers struggling to pay unaffordable bills , david cameron has allowed them to simply siphon money off year after year after year .

documents.title: michael dugher challenges tories to open tv debate negotiations
text: michael dugher , the shadow cabinet office minister , used his speech to the conference to challenge the tories to start talks about televised leaders ' debates during the general election .
conference , ed asked me to lead the negotiations for labour .
but the tories are always inventing reasons why the negotiations ca n't start .
we know the truth , conference .
the truth is david cameron does n't want to face ed miliband in those tv debates .
he does n't want to have to defend his record .
he 's got nothing to offer the country except more of the same .
he 's bottling it , conference .
20 million people watched the tv debates last time .
they may be called the 'prime ministerial tv debates ' , but they are not in the gift of the prime minister .
they belong to the public .
and it 's time to get on with it .
so today , i 'm writing to grant shapps to say enough is enough .
they should name their negotiators , fix a time and a place for the negotiations to begin and let 's get the tv debates sorted .
dugher also had a good gag about the tories being an endangered species .
today , conference , the tories do n't have a single councillor in manchester , in liverpool , in newham , harringey , oxford , norwich , chesterfield .
or in sheffield .
conference , we know there 's only one tory in sheffield - and that 's nick clegg .
so we have the tories on the run .
we see them hollowing out in every region across the country .
the average age of a conservative party member is now 69 .
their membership has nearly halved since david cameron became leader .
it now stands at around 134,000 .
conference , that makes a conservative party member officially an endangered species .

according to the international union for conservation of nature 's red list of threatened species , based on their current numbers , conservative party members are now officially rarer in numbers than hippos , chimpanzees , beluga whales - apologies to eric pickles - galapagos sea iguanas and something called the cloven-feathered dove , which , conference , i am told is a particularly rare type of pigeon .

documents.title: ed balls on his family inter-railing holiday and the sound of music
text: ed balls and yvette cooper 's family holidays sound a lot more adventurous than mine .
this is what balls told a fringe meeting last night about inter-railing through europe with his children , and making sound of music costumes on the train .
( he 's a huge fan . )
i had never been inter-railing when i was a student and i always slightly regretted it yvette did .

we were talking about how our children are a certain age , we had never been inter-railing , we looked it up and actually you do n't have to be 21 and smelly to go inter railing - you can do it at any age and also you do n't have to get trains at midnight or sleep on stations .

we decided we would go on an inter-railing trip , we started in london , got an inter rail ticket , and we went london , paris , munich , salzburg , venice , ancona , over to greece and flew back on ryan air - that was our holiday .

yvette was on the internet searching up what you can do in different cities and she suddenly comes running in and says 'i ca n't believe it - in salzburg the birthplace of mozart , they have this amazing thing called the sound of music tour ' .

it 's a british tour company and they do a three-hour trip where you each have a bike with a basket , like maria has , and they have a beatbox with all the songs , and they take you on a guided tour around all the sights playing the music , you run through a meadow and jump , you go to where the nuns look out .
and then , yvette said , if we do it we must make clothes out of curtain .
and so she bought some curtain material and on the train from munich to salzburg we sat there sewing .

for the teenage lads , she made some lederhosen , the girls had head scarves and a neckerchief we then cycled round austria wearing similar curtain material things for three hours , singing the sound of music saying we really , really hope nobody takes a photo of this because it would be really mortifying .
julie andrews in the sound of music /20th century fox/sportsphoto ltd./allstar
harriet harman , labour 's deputy leader , was also giving interviews this morning .

she seemed to concede that ed miliband might not appear as prime ministerial as david cameron ( a point repeatedly borne out by the polls ) , but she said that was just because he was n't actually prime minister .
i think when you are the leader of the opposition , you know , the prime minister always looks like the prime minister and the leader of the opposition looks like somebody who is n't prime minister .
but i think that ed miliband has got all the qualities of leadership that is needed , not only to be a good leader of us when we are in opposition but to be a great prime minister .
if you 're a political obsessive , this site is a treat .
it 's a mysociety initiative posting party conference speeches online .
you would assume that party conference speeches are easy to find online already , but often they are not .
mysociety has been trying to get round that by creating its own archive .

documents.title: chuka umunna 's interviews - summary
text: and here are some more lines from chuka umunna 's interviews this morning .
he was on sky news and today .

i heard him in full on today and he was good , disarming sarah montague rather effectively by providing a running commentary on her facial expressions , and nick robinson 's , as they were responding to what he was saying .
here are the key points from both interviews .
i 've taken some of the quotes from politicshome .
umunna said the mansion tax proposed by labour would only affect a tiny proportion '' of owners .
he said details of the tax would be announced nearer the election , but he suggested it could be levied when a home is sold .
to be frank , these things are usually levied when someone seeks to sell a property , '' he said .
( under the lib dem mansion tax plan , a charge would be levied annually . )
he said labour would produce a pledge card before the general election .
he said labour wanted the uk to have the lowest rate of corporation tax in the g7 .
he indicated that labour would make staying in the eu the big business issue at the general election .

the airbus boss , robin southwell , stressed the important of britain staying in the eu in a speech to the conference yesterday , he said : for business , that is the big issue at this general election .

there is only one party that can say that we will see the continued membership of the uk of the european union and that we wo n't put that at risk.radio 4 today ( @ bbcr4today ) here 's @ twitterid before speaking to @ twitterid montague on # r4today at @ # lab14
my colleague john harris has produced one of his wonderful politics videos .
he 's been looking at the impact of the scottish referendum on british politics .

documents.title: umunna suggests labour could back air strikes against isis
text: the american air strikes against islamic state ( isis ) have been extended to syria and it seems likely that david cameron may soon ask parliament to endorse britain joining in ( although perhaps just for air strikes against isis in iraq ) .
my colleague matthew weaver is covering all the latest developments on a separate live blog .
chuka umunna , the shadow business secretary , was asked about this in interviews this morning .
he made three important points .
umunna said downing street had not formally asked labour if it would support a motion to back air strikes , as far as he was aware .
he hinted that labour would back military action of some kind .
in terms of where the public is on this , i do think the public draws a distinction between the is situation and what was being proposed in syria last year .
i think the public are in a different place .
he explained what criteria labour would used to decide whether or not to back air strikes .

the labour party will apply the same criteria to whether or not we choose to support the intervention as we applied to the proposed syrian action last year - is there a legal basis to intervene , is there a plan for intervention , and , importantly as well , learning the lessons from iraq , is there a plan for what happens after ?
update at 11.30am : earlier i left out a not '' .
umunna said downing street had not formally asked labour to support a motion backing air strikes .
i 've corrected that now .

those of you who have ploughed your way through the labour briefing on ed miliband 's six-point plan that i posted below ( well done ) will have noticed that it says nothing about using money from the mansion tax to fund the nhs .
that was n't a line released by the party at its pre-speech briefing .
so how did it get out early ?
partly because journalists started chasing up an intriguing hint in a ( very good ) blog that damian mcbride , gordon brown 's former spin doctor , posted about ed balls 's speech .
as the tories are fond of reminding us , the revenues that will be raised from a mansion tax have already been spent more times than brewster 's millions .

but to be fair , labour have simply changed their mind as time has passed on what the priority should be for spending those revenues , and last time i looked , the current priority was the reintroduction of the 10p income tax band .
but today we learn that the 10p policy will instead be paid for by abolishing cameron 's cherished marriage tax break , neatly demolished by balls in his speech .
so how is the mansion tax money now going to be spent ?
when brown was chancellor , his team seemed to spend half their time at labour conference finding ways of upstaging the party leader .
some habits die hard

documents.title: cooper says labour would scrap the conservatives ' migration target
text: labour will scrap the conservatives ' target to reduce net migration below 100,000 if they are elected next year , the shadow home secretary , yvette cooper , said last night .
she was speaking at a labour fringe meeting at the party conference and my colleague alan travis was there .
he 's sent me this .

cooper told a fringe meeting on immigration that despite the pledge to reduce net migration to the tens of thousands '' by the next election it stood at the same level - 243,000- as when david cameron and theresa may announced the target in 2010 .
the conservatives have admitted that the target , which the liberal democrats refused to support , will be difficult to meet '' by next may 's election .
cooper said the adoption of the target had completely distorted '' the government 's policy on immigration .
it has led to a squeeze particularly on overseas student numbers and on family migration in an attempt to reduce the numbers .

she said that one of the major problems with the target was that it did not distinguish between different kinds of migrants and counted overseas students , low skilled migrants and asylum seekers as if they were all the same .
she said that labour would replace the government 's net migration target with much more strictly defined series of targets and controls which did not include overseas students .
cooper also said it was also important that asylum seekers were treated completely separately from migrants as they were seeking protection .
she said : we would not have a net migration target because choosing net migration to focus on is the wrong thing .
we think immediately what should happen is that students , international university students , should be taken out of the net migration target straight away .
what you should instead have is a series of different controls and targets for different kinds of immigration . ''
yvette cooper at the labour conference yesterday , listening to her husband , ed balls , speak .
scarff/getty images

documents.title: miliband 's six-point plan for 2015 - full details
text: for the record , here are the key points from the briefing on the speech released by labour overnight .
this post is quite long , but i ca n't find this information anywhere on the web , and it does seem reasonable to report in some detail what the party is proposing .
the document says labour has a six-point plan for 2025 .
giving all young people a shot in life : ensure as many school-leavers go on to apprenticeships as go to university .
tackling the cost-of-living crisis : help working families share fairly in the wealth of our country so , when the economy grows , the wages of everyday working people grow at the same rate .
restoring the dream of home ownership : meet demand for new homes for the first time in half a century - doubling the number of first-time buyers getting on to the housing ladder a year .
tackling low wages : halve the number of people on low pay in our country , changing the lives of over two million people .
securing the future : create one million more high-tech jobs by securing the uk 's position as is a world leader in green industries .
saving our nhs : build a world-class , 21st century health and care service .
and here are more details from the news release about those six priorities .
apprenticeships goal 1 : apprenticeships in 2025 : ensure as many school-leavers go on to apprenticeships as go to university .
the challenge : there are not enough advanced , high quality apprenticeships available for school-leavers - with four times as many going to university instead .
this is leaving both young people and businesses without the skills they need to succeed for the future .
labour 's plan for the first years of the next government · require every firm getting a major government contract to offer apprenticeships .
· insist that large employers hiring skilled workers from outside the eu offer apprenticeships to young people in the uk .
· give employers more control over how the government spends training funds in return for them providing more high quality apprenticeships in their sectors and supply chains .
· create thousands more apprenticeships in the public sector , including the civil service , creating a fast track scheme like that already existing for graduates from top universities .
· focusing apprenticeships on new entrants to the labour market , because under this government more than 75 per cent of new apprenticeships have gone to over 25 year olds .

living standards goal 2 : living standards in 2025 : help working families share fairly in the wealth of our country so , when the economy grows , the wages of everyday working people grow at the same rate .
the challenge : the link between the wealth of our nation and family finances has been broken resulting in a cost-of-living crisis for millions of everyday working people .

even after months of economic recovery , the average worker is more than £ 1,600 worse off than in 2010 while britain 's growing army of self-employed - now standing at five million - have seen their living standards fall 14 per cent since 2009/10 .

labour 's plan for the first years of the next government : · ensuring britain 's army of self-employed people see the benefits of going out to work by stopping them being locked out of mortgages or pensions .
· improving skills and productivity with new gold standard vocational qualifications and more high quality apprenticeships .
· supporting small firms with a cut in business rates and giving them access to the finance they need through a proper british investment bank and a more competitive banking system .
· building growth across all regions of the country by devolving £ 30 billion of funding and giving control over the full revenue from business rates to powerhouse economic regions .
· introducing an industrial strategy in sectors which create the high skill , high wage jobs of the future , including ten year certainty for science and innovation budgets .
housing goal 3 : housing in 2025 : meet demand for new homes for the first time in half a century - doubling the number of first-time buyers getting on to the housing ladder a year .

the challenge : housebuilding has reached its lowest level in peacetime since the 1920s and the dream of home ownership is slipping out of reach for millions of young families with the number of first-time buyers under this government averaging less than 200,000 a year .
labour 's plan for the first years of the next government · increase the number of new homes being built to at least 200,000 homes a year by the end of the next parliament .
· create new olym delivery agencies called new homes corporations to drive through large scale housing development at pace .
· make building new homes , including in the public sector , a top priority in our capital investment programme over the next parliament .
· give 'use it or lose it ' powers for local communities to tackle developers who hoard land unnecessarily .
· deliver a new generation of garden cities and give landlocked councils a right to grow .
low wages goal 5 : low pay in 2025 .
labour will halve the number of people on low pay in our country , changing the lives of over two million people .
the challenge : the number of workers on low pay now stands at over five million - a fifth of all employees - with half of all people in poverty now living in working households .
the proportion of uk workers who are low paid is one of the worst in the developed world - 25th out of a league table of 30 oecd countries .

labour 's plan for the first years of the next government · raise the national minimum wage to £ 8 an hour by the end of the next parliament , double the increase under this government and bringing the lowest paid closer to average earnings .
· strengthen enforcement of the national minimum wage by increasing the penalty for non-payment to £ 50,000 and giving local authorities new powers to support the work of hmrc .

· offer 'make work pay ' contracts to those accrediting as living wage employers , with firms getting a tax rebate worth up to £ 1,000 per worker funded by the increased tax and national insurance revenues the treasury receives .

green jobs goal 4 : green technology in 2025 : create one million more high-tech jobs by securing the uk 's position as is a world leader in green industries the challenge : climate change is real , man-made and happening .

but the tories have betrayed their promises on the environment , undermining britain 's ability to compete for a global green industry market worth £ 3.4 trillion a year with investment in clean energy falling .

labour 's plan for the first years of the next government · a clear commitment to tackling climate change by supporting an ambitious , legally-binding international agreement on climate change at the paris conference in 2015 · boosting investment in low-carbon technologies by a setting a legal target to remove the carbon from our electricity supply by 2030 and developing an active industrial strategy for the green economy .
· strengthening the green investment bank so it can invest in the technologies and industries of the future .
· devolving power to ensure 5 million homes are insulated .

nhs goal 6 - the nhs in 2025 : build a world-class , 21st century health and care service the challenge : the tories have n't just de-stabilised the health service and wasted billions on a top-down reorganisation , they are holding the nhs back from meeting the challenges of the 21st century : an ageing population , more people living with chronic conditions , the rise of mental health , and a higher premium on preventing illness .

as a result , the nhs is going backwards with one in four patients waiting a week or more for a gp appointment , the number of older people ending up in hospital unnecessarily at an all-time high because of inadequate social care , and waiting lists at their highest for six years .
labour 's plan for the first years of the next government : · guaranteeing 48 hour access to gps to improve services and ease pressure on a & e at hospitals .
· repealing the government 's health & social care act to put the right values back at the heart of the nhs and stop wasteful spending .
· integrating health and care services , ensuring joined-up , preventative care to help keep people healthy out of hospital .
· strengthening patient entitlements , including to mental health treatments .

it 's the highlight of the week at manchester , ed miliband 's last speech to a labour conference before the general election , and any readers of the rightwing papers today will be absolutely baffled as to what he stands for .

the sun headlines its story red ed 's 10 yr plan '' and it says that , by outlining a six-point plan , miliband is conjuring up communist party imagery of the five-year plans used by chinese communist leader mao tse-tung and russian tyrant joseph stalin '' .
but if you read the print edition of the daily telegraph , it will tell you miliband is emulating a different political icon .

miliband echoes maggie with homes pledge , '' says the headline above a story saying that miliband 's plan to double the number of first-time buyers by 2025 shows a thatcherite commitment to home ownership .
as usual , it 's best to read the guardian to find out what 's really going on .
like most other papers , we report that miliband plans to use money from the mansion tax to raise more money for the nhs .
but patrick wintour also reveals that miliband is also going to propose a windfall tax on the profits of tobacco companies to help fund the nhs .
here 's how his story starts .

ed miliband is to put the nation 's health at the centre of a 10-year plan for britain 's future on tuesday , backing the nhs with funding from a novel windfall tax on the profits of uk tobacco companies and the proceeds of a mansion tax on homes worth more than £ 2m .

in his final labour party conference speech before next year 's general election , miliband will tell sceptical voters he can bring the country back together and offer six ambitious goals , including changes to the nhs , designed to overcome the greatest challenges of our age and transform the ethics of how britain is run '' over the next decade .

the nhs is generally acknowledged to be facing a growing funding crisis after four years of tight settlements , deepening demographic pressure and an inefficient system that splits health and social care .
the nuffield trust has suggested there will be a financial shortfall of £ 2bn in 2015-16 .
overall miliband 's performance as a party leader has been patchy but he has excelled at giving conference speeches .
often these events attract a flurry of interest on the day , only to be completely forgotten seven days later .
but for the last three years - predator capitalism in 2011 , one nation labour in 2013 , and the energy price freeze in 2014 - miliband has been able to pull off agenda-setting speeches that last .
today we 'll see if he can do it again .
here 's the agenda for the day 9.40am : conference opens with nec reports .
10.05am : mohammad taj , the incoming tuc president , speaks .
10.15am : michael dugher , the shadow cabinet office minister , speaks .

10.20am : debate on living standards and sustainability , with speeches from maria eagle , the shadow environment secretary , mary creagh , the shadow transport secretary , and caroline flint , the shadow energy secretary .
2pm : ed miliband 's speech .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
